questions.text: Which of the following are branches of anterior division of the internal iliac artery? Superior gluteal artery Inferior gluteal artery Superior vesical artery Middle rectal artery Inferior vesical artery Vaginal artery Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,3,4,5,6 The nine branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery may be more easily remembered in these divisions: "three urinary": umbilical artery, superior vesical artery, inferior vesical artery "three visceral": uterine artery, vaginal artery, middle rectal artery "three parietal": obturator artery, internal pudendal artery, inferior gluteal artery Branches of Posterior division Iliolumbar artery Lateral sacral arteries Superior gluteal artery

Highyeild:

The internal iliac artery arises at the bifurcation of the common iliac artery, opposite the lumbosacral articulation, and, passing downward to the upper margin of the greater sciatic foramen, divides into two large trunks, an anterior and a posterior. It is posterior to the ureter, anterior to the internal iliac vein,anterior to the lumbosacral trunk, and anterior to the piriformis muscle. Near its origin, it is medial to the external iliac vein, which lies between it and the psoas major muscle. It is above the obturator nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- A. 1,4,5,6 C. 2,3,4,6 D. 1,2,3,5 Superior gluteal artery is a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.

Extraedge:

The following are the branches of internal iliac artery: Division Type Branch Sub-branches To/through Anterior Vesical Superior vesical artery (usually from the umbilical artery ) Sometimes middle vesicular upper urinary bladder and ureters Umbilical artery Artery to vas deferens (male) and Superior vesical artery (usually, but sometimes it branches directly from anterior trunk) medial umbilical ligament Inferior vesical artery (male) - lower urinary bladder and ureters Visceral Middle rectal artery - lower rectum Vaginal artery (female) the artery usually takes the place of the inferior vesical artery present in the male - vagina Uterine artery (female) vaginal branch uterus and cervix Parietal Obturator artery (occasionally from the inferior epigastric artery ) - obturator canal Internal pudendal artery many branches greater sciatic foramen and lesser sciatic foramen to perineum Inferior gluteal artery - greater sciatic foramen (inferior to piriformis muscle ) and gluteus maximus muscle Posterior Parietal Iliolumbar artery lumbar and iliac branches psoas major muscle , quadratus lumborum muscle , iliacus muscle Lateral sacral artery superior and inferior branches anterior sacral foramina Superior gluteal artery - gluteus maximus muscle

questions.text: In a subclavian artery block at the outer border of 1st rib, which of the following arteries help in maintaining the circulation to the upper limb? Suprascapular artery Superior thoracic artery Thyrocervical trunk Subscapular artery Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,3 and 4 A rich anastomosis exists around the scapula between branches of the subclavian artery (first part) and the axillary artery (third part). This anastomosis provides a collateral circulation through which blood can flow to the limb when the distal part of subclavian artery or the proximal part of axillary artery is blocked.

Highyeild:

Scapular anastomosis between branches of proximal subclavian and distal axillary artery: Branches of Subclavian artery: Thyrocervical trunk, Suprascapular and Deep branch of Transverse cervical artery. Branches of Axillary artery: Subscapular, Posterior circumflex humeral and Thoracoacromial arteries. Scapular anastomosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- A. 1,2,3 and 4 C. 1 and 3 D. 1, 2 and 3 Superior thoracic artery does not contribute to scapular anastomosis.

Extraedge:

Anastomosis Over the Acromion Process It is formed by: The acromial branch of the thoracoacromial artery (2nd part of axillary). The acromial branch of the suprascapular artery (1st part of subclavian) The acromial branch of the posterior circumflex humeral artery (3rd part of axillary).

questions.text: Most specific complication if the central line is inserted below this bone?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arterial injury Left clavicle is shown in the image. Arterial puncture/injury is the most common while cardiac tamponade is the most fatal complication of central venous catheterization.

Highyeild:

Complications for central venous catheterization apart from failure to place the catheter include arterial puncture, cardiac tamponade, catheter malposition, pneumothorax (Injury to the parietal pleura )/chylothorax (Venous congestion or injury to lymphatics mainly in left sided insertion), infections, Thromboembolism, subcutaneous hematoma, hemothorax, nerve injury (recurrent laryngeal nerve MCly, also sympathetic chain, brachial plexus, and phrenic nerve) and cardiac arrest. Among these, arterial puncture/injury is the most common while cardiac tamponade is the most fatal complication. Arterial puncture is often easily recognized secondary to pulsatile flow, but recognition may be difficult in a hypotensive and critically-ill patient. Arterial injury occurs most commonly in femoral catheter placement and least commonly in subclavian placement.

Extraedge:

There are three main access sites for the placement of central venous catheters, namely internal jugular, common femoral, and subclavian veins. These are the preferred sites for temporary prominent venous catheter placement. Additionally, for mid-term and long-term central venous access, the basilic and brachial veins are utilized for peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs).

questions.text: A male patient who has already taken the first dose for COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. The health worker then noticed that his shoulder was flat, flabby and looked asymmetrical due to loss of contour. Which of these structures would have been injured to lead to this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deltoid Given scenario is typical for shoulder dislocation. On examination , there is often an asymmetry with the contralateral side. Often there is a loss of shoulder contours (from a ‘flattened deltoid’) and an anterior bulge from the head of the humerus may also be seen. It is important to assess the neurovascular status of the arm, which can become compromised in some cases, especially the axillary and suprascapular nerves.

Highyeild:

Associated Injuries of shoulder Bony: Bony Bankart lesions are fractures of the anterior inferior glenoid bone, most commonly present in those with recurrent dislocations Hill-Sachs defects are impaction injuries to the chondral surface of the posterior and superior portions of the humeral head, present in approximately 80% of traumatic dislocations Fractures of the greater tuberosity and the surgical neck of the humerus can also occur. Hill-sachs and Bankart shoulder injury Labral, ligamentous, and rotator cuff: (Soft) Bankart lesions are avulsions of the anterior labrum and inferior glenohumeral ligament Glenohumeral ligament avulsion Rotator cuff injuries occur frequently in anterior dislocations; in younger patients, around a third have at least one tear

Extraedge:

The deltoid muscle is large and triangular in shape, with its base attached to the scapula and clavicle and its apex attached to the humerus. It originates along a continuous U-shaped line of attachment to the clavicle and the scapula, mirroring the adjacent insertion sites of the trapezius muscle. It inserts into the deltoid tuberosity on the lateral surface of the shaft of the humerus. The major function of the deltoid muscle is abduction of the arm beyond the initial 1 5 ° accomplished by the supraspinatus muscle.

questions.text: A neonate develops RDS. Which of the following areas have problems?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C Given image shows an electron microscopic view of alveolus and its structures. Respiratory distress syndrome is caused due to abnormality of type II pneumocytes. Given image shows an electron microscopic view of alveolus and its structures. The interstitium at is tissue between two layers of alveolar epithelial cells containing elastic and collagen fibers produced by fibroblasts (also known as septal cells). There is no connective tissue over the capillaries.

Highyeild:

Type II pneumocytes protruding into alveolar lumen is seen in this image. Arrows indicate lamellar bodies containing the phospholipids that when released spread over the alveolar surface where they combine with other carbohydrate- and protein-containing secretory products (some of which are derived from Clara cells) to overcome the effects of surface tension which would otherwise cause the alveolar walls to adhere. This allows for normal inflation of the alveoli at birth and for the reinflation of alveoli which collapse after airway obstruction. Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), Golgi (G), reticular fibers (RF). Note the microvilli of the type II cell and junctional complexes (JC) with type I cell.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- A- Nucleus of endothelial cells B- Cytoplasmic extensions of Type I alveolar cells D- endothelial cells Respiratory distress syndrome is caused due to abnormality of type II pneumocytes, therefore Option A, B and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) occurs in babies born early (premature) whose lungs are not fully developed. The earlier the infant is born, the more likely it is for them to have RDS and need extra oxygen and help breathing. RDS is caused by the baby not having enough surfactant in the lungs.

questions.text: A patient with a fall from a height was treated with a cast. After removal of the cast, he was not able to walk properly, unable to lift his leg and was dragging his right leg while walking. Which of the following marked structures is involved?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Here, the case scenario points to a possible injury to gluteus medius which is causing lurching gait and dragging of feet in the patient. Dissected right gluteal region has been shown in the image. PM: piriformis muscle; SN: sciatic nerve; GM: gluteus medius; SGN: superior gluteal nerve; *: additional belly of piriformis muscle Abductors of hip are – Gluteus medius and minimus (main) Tensor fascia lata and sartorius (accessory) The left gluteal region after reflecting gluteus maximus muscle Figure: The left gluteal region after reflecting gluteus maximus muscle; CFn — common fibular nerve; Tn — tibial nerve; IGv — inferior gluteal vessels; Pfm — piriformis muscle; GM — gluteus medius; QF — quadratus femoris muscle; GMx — gluteus maximus muscle; Sn — sciatic nerve.

Highyeild:

Normally when the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei (medius and minimus) of the supported side contract and raise the opposite and unsupported side of pelvis, if the abductor mechanism is defective the unsupported side of pelvis drops and lurching gait is seen (as positive Trendelenburg’s test).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Superior gluteal nerve Option C- Piriformis Option D- Sciatic nerve Here, the case scenario points to a possible injury to gluteus medius which is causing lurching gait and dragging of feet in the patient, therefore option B,C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

The Trendelenburg Position —patient supine on a table tilted 45° downwards with legs and feet over the edge of the table—was the 'egg of Columbus', a position necessary during abdominal and pelvic operations.

questions.text: The following cell marked as A is inhibitory to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deep nuclei of cerebellum Cell marked as A is Purkinje cell in cerebellar cortex and it is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei. Axons of Purkinje cells are inhibitory. They project to and inhibit the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Highyeild:

Cerebellar cortex: Molecular layer (outer) - granule cells axons, Purkinje cells dendrites, stellate cells, basket cells Purkinje layer (middle) - Purkinje cell bodies Granular layer (inner) - granule cell bodies, Golgi cells, Purkinje cell axons.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Vestibular nuclei Option C. Anterior horn of spinal Cord Option D. Basal ganglia Cell marked as A is Purkinje cell in cerebellar cortex and it is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei, therefore option A,C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

The ultimate destination of the afferent pathways to the cerebellar cortex is the Purkinje cell . However, the input from the cerebral cortex to the Purkinje cells is quite indirect. Neurons in the pontine nuclei receive a projection from the cerebral cortex and then relay the information to the contralateral cerebellar cortex. The axons from the pontine nuclei and other sources are called mossy fibers because of the appearance of their synaptic terminals. Mossy fibers synapse on granule cells in the granule cell layer of the cerebellar cortex. The cerebellar granule cells are the most abundant class of neurons in the human brain and give rise to specialized axons called parallel fibers that ascend to the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex. The parallel fibers bifurcate in the molecular layer to form T-shaped branches that relay information via excitatory synapses onto the dendritic spines of the Purkinje cells. Neuronal types in the cerebellar cortex . Note that the various neuron classes are found in distinct layers. Diagram showing convergent inputs onto the Purkinje cell from parallel fibers and local circuit neurons . The output of the Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei .

questions.text: Fibres from the labelled structure end in which thalamic nuclei?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior Mamillary body has been shown in the labelled image. Fibers from the mamillary body end in anterior thalamic nuclei.

Highyeild:

Internal medullary lamina divides thalamus into: Anterior nuclear groups Medial nuclear groups Lateral nuclear groups Schematic diagram drawn below shows important parts of thalamus in an anticlockwise fashion: Anterior nucleus Ventral nuclear group: Anterior Lateral Posterior Medial Lateral Lateral and Medial geniculate body Medial-Dorsal nucleus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Ventrolateral Option C- Median Option D- Posteromedial Mamillary body has been shown in the labelled image. Fibers from the mamillary body end in anterior thalamic nuclei, therefore option B, C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

Thalamus Nucleus Function "A" for Anterior nucleus A for: ● Alertness ● Attention ● Affect Acute memory These are the functions of limbic "B" for Ventral- anterior nucleus B for: Basal ganglia ● Afferent: Globus pallidus and Substantia nigra ● Efferent: Brodmann Area 6 (Prefrontal and premotor cortex) "C" for Ventral- lateral nucleus C for: Co-ordination and Cerebellum ● Afferent: Cerebellum (Dentate nucleus) and Basal ganglia ● Efferent: Brodmann Area 4 (Primary motor cortex) "D" for Ventral-Posterior nucleus D for: Dermatome (Sensory) ● Afferent: ● Ventro-postero-medial (VPM) nucleus: Trigemino-thalamic tract, Solitario-thalamic tract ● Medial Mask (face) ● Taste (Nucleus tractus solitarius) ● Ventro-postero-lateral (VPL) nucleus: ● Spinothalamic tract ● Medial lemniscus ● Efferent: ● Brodmann Area 3, 1, 2 (Sensory cortex)

Table:

#MANTRA Main Thalamic nucleus and their connections Group Nucleus Major subcortical connection Major cortical connections System Anterior Anterior Mammillary bodies (MTT) Cingulate and parahippocampal gyrus Relay limbic Medial Dorsomedial Amygdala, thalamic nuclei Prefrontal cortex Association Lateral Ventral VA GPm, SNr Premotor cortex Relay motor VL Ipsilateral GPM, contralateral cerebellum Supplementary and primary motor cortex Relay motor VPI, VPm STT to VPI, TTT to VPm, MLT to anterior surface Somatosensory cortex, insula Relay somato- sensory LGB Optic tract Visual cortex Relay visual MGB Auditory pathway (inferior brachium) Auditory cortex Relay auditory Dorsal Pulvinar LP Superior colliculus Parieto-occipito-temporal Association LD Pretectum and superior colliculus Cingulate, parahippocampus Intralaminar CM GPm, cerebellum Striatum, motor cortex Reticular Widespread connections Widespread connections (afferent only)

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery supplies which of these parts- Thyroid gland Parathyroid gland Oesophagus Thymus Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3,4 The inferior thyroid artery is the principal blood supplier of the thyroid gland (supplies the lower half). The ITA gives rise to the ascending cervical artery, the inferior laryngeal artery, and also gives pharyngeal, tracheal, and esophageal branches. Also, the ITA supplies the four parathyroid glands.

Highyeild:

Inferior thyroid artery arises from the thyrocervical trunk (a branch of the subclavian artery) and penetrates thyroid on its posterior side. It lies in close proximity to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (innervates the larynx)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. 1 and 3 Option B. 1,2,3 Option C. 1,2,4 The Inferior thyroid artery gives rise to the ascending cervical artery, the inferior laryngeal artery, and also gives pharyngeal, tracheal,Parathyroid,thyroid and esophageal branches.

Extraedge:

The inferior thyroid artery is an artery in the neck. It arises from the thyrocervical trunk and passes upward, in front of the vertebral artery and longus colli muscle. It then turns medially behind the carotid sheath and its contents, and also behind the sympathetic trunk, the middle cervical ganglion resting upon the vessel. Reaching the lower border of the thyroid gland it divides into two branches, which supply the postero-inferior parts of the gland, and anastomose with the superior thyroid artery, and with the corresponding artery of the opposite side.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve fibres can be seen here?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV The Dorsal part of the brainstem is marked here, CN 4 or trochlear nerve is seen passing through this area. The olfactory nerve (CN I) and optic nerve (CN II) originate from the cerebrum.

Highyeild:

Cranial nerves III – XII arise from the brain stem. They can arise from a specific part of the brain stem (midbrain, pons or medulla), or from a junction between two parts: Midbrain – the trochlear nerve (IV) comes from the posterior side of the midbrain. It has the longest intracranial length of all the cranial nerves. Midbrain-pontine junction – oculomotor (III). Pons – trigeminal (V). Pontine-medullary junction – abducens, facial, vestibulocochlear (VI-VIII). Medulla oblongata – posterior to the olive: glossopharyngeal, vagus, accessory (IX-XI). Anterior to the olive: hypoglossal (XII). Cranial nerves III – XII arise from the brain stem

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. III Midbrain-pontine junction – oculomotor (III) nerve emerges out. Option B. VII Pontine-medullary junction – abducens, facial, vestibulocochlear (VI-VIII), emerges out. Option D. VI Pontine-medullary junction – abducens, facial, vestibulocochlear (VI-VIII) emerges out.

Extraedge:

Structures emerging out from cranial foramina

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the marked structure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supra cardinal vein Azygos vein is shown in the image above, and it develops from the supracardinal vein.

Highyeild:

During embryogenesis the earliest veins develop from capillary plexuses; these carry blood into the sinus venosus , the in-flow end of the forming heart. The right and left common cardinal veins drain directly into the sinus venosus (see Figure). Developmental source of important veins The common cardinal veins form at the junction of the anterior and posterior cardinal veins on both sides. Most veins, caudal to the heart, develop from the sub- and supracardinal veins, which arise dorsal and ventral to the regressed posterior cardinal veins, respectively. The subcardinal veins anastomose with each other (subcardinal anastomosis) and with the supracardinal veins (sub supracardinal anastomosis). The majority of the left-sided cardinal veins regress. The right subcardinal vein develops to drain most of the upper, the right supracardinal vein most of the lower part of the abdomen. Majority of the azygos system develops from the cranial part of the supracardinal veins. The infrarenal segment of the inferior vena cava (IVC) develops from the caudal right supracardinal vein. The renal segment of the IVC arises from the sub supracardinal anastomosis, a venous network located circumferentially around the aorta (renal collar). Eventually, the posterior segment of the collar regresses and the anterior part gives the left renal vein .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Common Cardinal vein Option B. Sub cardinal vein Option C. Sacrocardinal vein Azygos vein is shown in the image above, and it develops from the supracardinal vein, therefore option A,B and C are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

The hemiazygos vein (vena azygos minor inferior) is a vein running superiorly in the lower thoracic region, just to the left side of the vertebral column.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the image given:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Levator ani is marked A in the given image. Levator ani muscle forms major part of pelvic diaphragm It forms the roof of ischioanal fossa. Ischiorectal fossa

Highyeild:

The pelvic floor or pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition separating the pelvic cavity (above), and perineal region (including the perineum) (below). It is formed by the levator ani muscle and coccygeus muscle, and associated connective tissue. The pelvic floor has two hiatuses (gaps): (anteriorly) the urogenital hiatus through which urethra and vagina pass, and (posteriorly) the rectal hiatus through which the anal canal passes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- B is deep part of external anal sphincter Option B- D is Pudendal canal Option C- C is internal anal sphincter

Extraedge:

Pelvic diaphragm is important in providing support for pelvic viscera (organs), e.g. the bladder, intestines, the uterus (in females), and in maintenance of continence as part of the urinary and anal sphincters. It facilitates birth by resisting the descent of the presenting part, causing the fetus to rotate forwards to navigate through the pelvic girdle. It helps maintain optimal intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.text: 3rd part of the vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B Given image shows the 1 st cervical vertebra also known as atlas. 3 rd part of the vertebral artery is related to the posterior arch of atlas. V3 (extradural or extraspinal) curves and twists across the top of the C1 vertebra (the atlas) until it enters the skull. V4 (intradural or intracranial) enters the skull. The right and left vertebral arteries then join together to form the basilar artery. Atlas vertebrae

Highyeild:

ALSO NOTE: The transverse foramina of the cervical vertebrae provide a passageway by which the vertebral artery , vein and sympathetic nerves can pass. The only exception to this is C7 – where the vertebral artery passes around the vertebra, instead of through the transverse foramen. The spinal nerves are intimately related to the cervical vertebrae. They extend from above their respective vertebrae, through the intervertebral foramen created by the joints at the articular processes. Again, C7 is an exception – it has a set of spinal nerves extending from above (C7) and below (C8) the vertebra. Therefore, there are eight spinal nerves associated with seven cervical vertebrae.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C and D are incorrect because Option A is the posterior arch of atlas, related to the 3rd part of the vertebral artery.

Extraedge:

The vertebral arteries are major arteries of the neck. Typically, the vertebral arteries originate from the subclavian arteries. Each vessel courses superiorly along each side of the neck, merging within the skull to form the single, midline basilar artery. As the supplying component of the vertebrobasilar vascular system, the vertebral arteries supply blood to the upper spinal cord, brainstem, cerebellum, and posterior part of the brain.

questions.text: Which part of the scapula is seen in infraclavicular fossa?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A The coracoid process is an osseous structure that arises from the superior border of the head of the scapula, projecting forward and curving laterally. The coracoid process is located directly below the lateral fourth of the clavicle and connected to its under surface by the coracoclavicular ligament. Coracoid process is seen and palpated in infraclavicular fossa. This can be seen retrospectively as :The boundaries of the infraclavicular fossa are the pectoralis minor and major muscles anteriorly, ribs medially, clavicle and CORACOID PROCESS SUPERIORLY. SCAPULA

Highyeild:

The most common etiology of a winged scapula is usually due to damage or impaired innervation to the serratus anterior muscle. The nerve that innervates this muscle is the long thoracic nerve. Sometimes, this nerve can be damaged or impinged, leading to malfunction of the serratus anterior muscle.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B is acromial process of scapula Option C is Glenoid cavity of scapula Option D is inferior angle of scapula

Extraedge:

Fractures of the scapula are relatively uncommon, and if they do occur, it is an indication of severe chest trauma. They are frequently seen in high speed road collisions, crushing injuries, or sports injuries. The fractured scapula does not typically require fixation as the tone of the surrounding muscles holds the pieces in place for healing to occur.
